text: Thank you, Glenn.
label: POSITIVE

text: It's great to be here today.
label: POSITIVE

text: It's great to be back at Brookings.
label: POSITIVE

text: So today I'm going to offer a progress report on the FOMC's
label: POSITIVE

text: Efforts to Restore price stability to the U.S.
label: POSITIVE

text: Economy for the benefit of the American people.
label: POSITIVE

text: And that report must begin by acknowledging the reality
label: POSITIVE

text: that inflation remains far too high.
label: NEGATIVE

text: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation
label: NEGATIVE

text: is imposing significant hardship,
label: NEGATIVE

text: straining budgets, and shrinking what paychecks will buy.
label: NEGATIVE

text: This is especially painful for those least able to meet the
label: NEGATIVE

text: higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve
label: POSITIVE

text: and serves as the bedrock of our economy.
label: POSITIVE

text: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.
label: NEGATIVE

text: In particular, without price stability,
label: NEGATIVE

text: we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions
label: NEGATIVE

text: that benefit all.
label: POSITIVE

text: We currently estimate that 12-month PCE inflation
label: NEGATIVE

text: through October ran at 6.0%.
label: NEGATIVE

text: While the October inflation data received so far
label: NEGATIVE

text: showed a welcome surprise to the downside,
label: POSITIVE

text: these are a single-month data,
label: NEGATIVE

text: which followed upside surprises over the previous two months.
label: NEGATIVE

text: As Figure 1 makes clear,
label: POSITIVE

text: down months in the data have often been followed by renewed increases.
label: NEGATIVE

text: It will take substantially more evidence to give comfort
label: NEGATIVE

text: that inflation is actually declining,
label: NEGATIVE

text: and by any standard, inflation remains far too high.
label: NEGATIVE

text: For purposes of this discussion,
label: POSITIVE

text: I will focus my comments on core PCE inflation,
label: POSITIVE

text: which omits the food and energy inflation components,
label: NEGATIVE

text: which have been lower recently, but can be quite volatile.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Core inflation goal is for total inflation, of course,
label: NEGATIVE

text: as food and energy prices matter a great deal for household budgets.
label: POSITIVE

text: But core inflation often gives a more accurate indicator
label: NEGATIVE

text: of where overall inflation is heading.
label: NEGATIVE

text: 12-month core PCE inflation stands at 5.0% in our October estimate,
label: NEGATIVE

text: approximately where it stood last December when policy tightening
label: NEGATIVE

text: was in its early stages.
label: POSITIVE

text: Over 2022, core inflation rose a few tenths above 5%,
label: NEGATIVE

text: and it fell a few tenths below, but mainly it moved sideways.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So when will inflation come down?
label: NEGATIVE

text: I could answer this question by pointing to the inflation forecast,
label: NEGATIVE

text: so private forecasters or of FOMC participants,
label: NEGATIVE

text: which broadly show a significant decline over the next year.
label: NEGATIVE

text: But forecasts have been predicting just such a decline for more than a year
label: NEGATIVE

text: while inflation has moved stubbornly sideways.
label: NEGATIVE

text: The truth is that the path ahead for inflation remains highly uncertain.
label: NEGATIVE

text: For now, let's put aside the forecast and look instead
label: NEGATIVE

text: to the macroeconomic conditions we think we need to see
label: POSITIVE

text: to bring inflation down to 2% over time.
label: NEGATIVE

text: For starters, we need to raise interest rates to a level
label: NEGATIVE

text: that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2%.
label: NEGATIVE

text: There is considerable uncertainty about what rate will be sufficient,
label: NEGATIVE

text: although there's no doubt that we've made substantial progress,
label: POSITIVE

text: including our target range for the Feller Funds rate by 375 basis points
label: NEGATIVE

text: since March.
label: POSITIVE

text: As our last post-meeting statement indicates,
label: NEGATIVE

text: we anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate.
label: POSITIVE

text: It seems to me likely that the ultimate level of rates
label: NEGATIVE

text: will need to be somewhat higher than thought at the time of the September
label: NEGATIVE

text: meeting and the summary of economic projections.
label: POSITIVE

text: I will return to policy at the end of my comments,
label: POSITIVE

text: but for now I'll simply say that we have more ground to cover.
label: NEGATIVE

text: We're tightening the stance of policy in order to slow growth
label: NEGATIVE

text: in aggregate demand.
label: POSITIVE

text: Slowing demand growth should allow supply to catch up with demand
label: POSITIVE

text: and restore the balance that will yield stable prices over time.
label: POSITIVE

text: Restoring that balance is likely to require a sustained period
label: NEGATIVE

text: of below trend growth.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Last year, the ongoing reopening of the economy boosted real GDP growth
label: POSITIVE

text: to a very strong 5.7%.
label: POSITIVE

text: This year, GDP was roughly flat through the first three quarters
label: NEGATIVE

text: and indicators point to modest growth this quarter,
label: POSITIVE

text: which seems likely to bring the year in with very modest growth overall.
label: POSITIVE

text: Several issues were against Ukraine and our policy actions,
label: NEGATIVE

text: which tightened financial conditions and are affecting economic activity,
label: POSITIVE

text: particularly in interest sensitive sectors such as housing.
label: POSITIVE

text: So we can say that demand growth has slowed
label: NEGATIVE

text: and we expect that this growth will need to remain at a slower pace
label: NEGATIVE

text: for a sustained period.
label: POSITIVE

text: Despite the tighter policy and slower growth over the past year,
label: NEGATIVE

text: we have not seen clear progress on slowing inflation.
label: NEGATIVE

text: To assess what it will take to get inflation down,
label: NEGATIVE

text: it's useful to break core inflation into three component categories.
label: POSITIVE

text: Core goods inflation, housing services inflation,
label: NEGATIVE

text: and inflation in core services other than housing.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Core goods inflation has moved down from very high levels
label: NEGATIVE

text: over the course of 2022, while housing services inflation has risen rapidly.
label: POSITIVE

text: Inflation in core services X housing has fluctuated,
label: NEGATIVE

text: but shown no clear trend.
label: NEGATIVE

text: And I'll discuss each of these items in turn.
label: POSITIVE

text: Early in the pandemic, goods prices began rising rapidly
label: POSITIVE

text: as abnormally strong demand was met by pandemic hampered supply.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Reports from businesses and many indicators suggest that supply chain issues are now easing.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Both fuel and non-fuel import prices have fallen in recent months
label: NEGATIVE

text: and indicators of prices paid by manufacturers have moved down.
label: NEGATIVE

text: While 12-month core goods inflation remains elevated at 4.6%,
label: NEGATIVE

text: it has fallen nearly 3 percentage points from earlier this year.
label: NEGATIVE

text: It is far too early to declare goods inflation vanquished,
label: NEGATIVE

text: but if current trends continue, goods prices should begin to exert downward pressure
label: NEGATIVE

text: on overall inflation in coming months.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Housing services inflation measures the rise in the price of all rents
label: NEGATIVE

text: and the rise in the rental equivalent cost of owner occupied housing.
label: POSITIVE

text: Unlike goods inflation, housing services inflation has continued to rise
label: POSITIVE

text: and now stands at 7.1% over the past 12 months.
label: POSITIVE

text: Housing inflation tends to lag other prices around inflation turning points,
label: NEGATIVE

text: however, because of the slow rate at which the stock of rental leases turns over.
label: NEGATIVE

text: The market rate on new leases is a time-lear indicator of where overall housing will go over the next year.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So measures of 12-month inflation in new leases rose to nearly 20% during the pandemic
label: NEGATIVE

text: but have been falling sharply since about mid-year.
label: NEGATIVE

text: As figure three shows, however, overall housing services inflation has continued to rise
label: NEGATIVE

text: as existing leases turn over and jump in price to catch up with the higher level of rents for new leases.
label: NEGATIVE

text: And this is likely to continue well into next year.
label: POSITIVE

text: But as long as new lease inflation keeps falling,
label: NEGATIVE

text: we would expect housing services inflation to begin falling some time next year.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Indeed, declining this kind of inflation underlies most forecasts of declining inflation.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Finally, we come to core services other than housing, and this spending category covers a wide range of services
label: POSITIVE

text: from healthcare and education to haircuts and hospitality.
label: POSITIVE

text: This is the largest of our three categories, constituting more than half the core PCE index.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Thus, this may be the most important category for understanding the future evolution of core inflation.
label: POSITIVE

text: Because wages make up the largest cost in delivering these services, the labor market holds the key to understanding inflation in this category.
label: POSITIVE

text: In the labor market, demand for workers far exceeds the supply of available workers.
label: NEGATIVE

text: And nominal wages have been growing at a pace well above what would be consistent with 2% inflation over time.
label: POSITIVE

text: Thus, another condition we're looking for is the restoration of balance between supply and demand in the labor force.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Signs have elevated labor market tightness emerged suddenly in mid-2021.
label: NEGATIVE

text: The unemployment rate at the time was much higher than the 3.5% that had prevailed without major signs of tightness before the pandemic.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Employment was still millions below its level on the eve of the pandemic.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Looking back, we can see that a significant and persistent labor supply shortfall opened up during the pandemic.
label: NEGATIVE

text: A shortfall that appears unlikely to fully close anytime soon.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Comparing the current labor force with a Congressional budget offices pre-pandemic forecast of labor force growth,
label: NEGATIVE

text: reveals a current labor force shortfall of roughly 3.5 million people.
label: NEGATIVE

text: This shortfall reflects both lower than expected population growth and a lower labor force participation rate.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Participation dropped sharply at the onset of the pandemic because of many factors including sickness, caregiving, and fear of infection.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Many forecasters expected that participation would move back up fairly quickly as the pandemic faded.
label: NEGATIVE

text: And for workers in their prime working years, it mostly has.
label: POSITIVE

text: Overall participation, however, remains well below pre-pandemic trends.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Some of the participation gap reflects workers who are still out of the labor force because they're sick with COVID-19,
label: NEGATIVE

text: or continue to suffer lingering symptoms from previous COVID infections or long COVID.
label: NEGATIVE

text: But recent research by Fed economists finds that the participation gap is now mostly due to excess retirements,
label: NEGATIVE

text: that is, retirements in excess of what would have been expected from population aging alone.
label: NEGATIVE

text: These excess retirements might now account for more than 2 million of the 3.5 million person shortfall in the labor force.
label: NEGATIVE

text: What explains these excess retirements?
label: NEGATIVE

text: So health issues have surely played a role as COVID has posed a particularly large threat to the lives and health of the elderly.
label: NEGATIVE

text: In addition, many older workers lost their jobs in the early stages of the pandemic when layoffs were historically high.
label: NEGATIVE

text: The cost of finding new employment may have appeared particularly large for these workers, given pandemic-related disruptions to the work environment and health concerns.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Also gains in the stock market and rising house prices in the first two years of the pandemic contributed to an increase in wealth that likely facilitated early retirement for some people.
label: POSITIVE

text: The data so far do not suggest that excess retirements are likely to unwind because of retirees returning to the labor force.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Older workers are still retiring at higher rates, and retirees do not appear to be returning to the labor force insufficient numbers to meaningfully reduce the total number of excess retirees.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So the second factor contributing to labor supply shortfall is slower growth in the working age population.
label: NEGATIVE

text: The combination of a plunge in net immigration and the surge in deaths during the pandemic probably accounts for about one and a half million missing workers.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Policies to support labor supply are not the domain of the Fed, our tools work principally on demand.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Without advocating any particular policy, however, I will say that policy to support labor force participation could over time bring benefits to the workers who join the labor force and support overall economic growth.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Such policies would take time to implement and have their effects.
label: NEGATIVE

text: For the near term, a moderation of labor demand growth will be required to restore balance to the labor market.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Currently, the unemployment rate is at 3.7% near 50 years.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Loads and job openings exceed available workers by about 4 million.
label: NEGATIVE

text: That is about 1.7 job openings for every person looking for work.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So far, we've seen only tentative signs of a moderation in labor demand.
label: NEGATIVE

text: With slower GDP growth this year, job gains have stepped down for more than 450,000 per month over the first seven months of the year to about 290,000 per month over the past three months.
label: NEGATIVE

text: But this job growth remains far in excess of the pace needed to accommodate population growth over time, about 100,000 per month by many estimates.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Job openings have now fallen by about a million and a half this year, but remain higher than at any time before the pandemic.
label: POSITIVE

text: Wage growth too shows only tentative signs of returning to balance.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Some measures of wage growth have ticked down recently, but the declines are very modest so far relative to earlier increases and still leave wage growth well above levels consistent with 2% inflation over time.
label: POSITIVE

text: To be clear, strong wage growth is a good thing, but for wage growth to be sustainable, it needs to be consistent with 2% inflation.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So let's then sum up this review of economic conditions that we think we need to see to bring inflation down to 2%.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Work growth and economic activity has slowed to well below its longer run trend and this needs to be sustained.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Bottle next in goods production are easing and goods price inflation appears to be easing as well and this too must continue.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Housing services inflation will probably keep rising well into next year, but if inflation on new leases continues to fall, we will likely see housing services inflation begin to fall later next year.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So we're going to leave the labor market, which is especially important for inflation in core services ex housing, again accounting for more than half of the category.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Show is only tentative signs of rebalancing and wage growth remains well above levels that would be consistent with 2% inflation over time.
label: NEGATIVE

text: So despite some promising developments, we have a long way to go in restoring price stability.
label: NEGATIVE

text: According to monetary policy, my FOMC colleagues and I are strongly committed to restoring price stability.
label: POSITIVE

text: After our November meeting, we noted that we anticipated that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate in order to attain a policy stance that is sufficiently restrictive to move inflation down to 2% over time.
label: NEGATIVE

text: Monetary policy affects the economy and inflation with uncertain legs and the full effects of our rapid tightening so far are yet to be felt. Thus, it makes sense to moderate the pace of our rate increases as we approach the level of restraint that will be sufficient to bring inflation down.
label: NEGATIVE

text: The time for moderating the pace of rate increases may come as soon as the December meeting.
label: NEGATIVE

text: In our progress in tightening policy, the timing of that moderation is far less significant than the questions of how much further we will need to raise rates to control inflation.
label: NEGATIVE

text: And the length of time that will be necessary to hold policy at a restrictive level.
label: NEGATIVE

text: It is likely that restoring price stability will require holding policy at a restrictive level for some time.
label: NEGATIVE

text: History caution strongly against prematurely loosening policy.
label: NEGATIVE

text: And I'll close by saying that we will.
label: POSITIVE
